Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ng-container with ViewContainerRef creates two comments
Issues.Body:
With Ivy, injecting a `ViewContainerRef` for a `<ng-container>` element
results in two comments generated in the DOM. One comment as host
element for the `ElementContainer` and one for the generated `LContainer`
which is needed for the created `ViewContainerRef`.

This is problematic as developers expect the same anchor element for
the `LContainer` and the `ElementContainer` in order to be able to move
the host element of `<ng-container>` without leaving the actual
`LContainer` anchor element at the original location.

This worked differently in View Engine and various applications might
depend on the behavior where the `ViewContainerRef` shares the anchor
comment node with the host comment node of the `<ng-container>`. For
example `CdkTable` from `@angular/cdk` moves around the host element of
a `<ng-container>` and also expects embedded views to be inserted next
to the moved `<ng-container>` host element.

See: https://github.com/angular/components/blob/f8be5329f8d94128ece5dfe3e8e998fe4077d44d/src/cdk/table/table.ts#L999-L1016

Resolves FW-1341

### Description
The `RequiredValidator` does not update its validation status when an input is autofilled in Chrome. This is problematic for users who set up a required username and password input and then conditionally enable the submit button when the inputs are valid. The user sees:

1. Page loads
2. Inputs are autofilled with username and password
3. Submit button is still disabled.

This issue has been filed in the past on the components repo: https://github.com/angular/components/issues/3414, though the change would really have to happen in @angular/forms.

@angular/cdk has an `AutofillMonitor` that could be moved to @angular/forms and used to detect when an input is autofilled.

Issues.Title: ReactiveForms directives - mark component for Changes (make reactive forms trully reactive)
Issues.Body:
# 🚀 feature request
@angular/forms


### Description
ReactiveForms is the main way how to handle forms, however i think they are not so reactive as they should be and it leads to big and easy to avoid boilerplate in code, main problems are:

- reactive forms directives do not mark component for checks. Why? It is very common scenario when you want to pass formControl / formGroup to "sub-edit" component. Developer has to do everytime the same - subscribe to status / value changes and markForCheck component manually. It doesnt respect the principle of least astonishment as well (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principle_of_least_astonishment) 

- i got ReactiveForms have methods like setValue / patchValue because of tests and for usage in non-reactive environment. However, if they are named reactive - they are missing still one thing -  reactive way to enable / disable form parts..  

- statusChanges push notifications only for validity - they should push notifications for ALL status changes.. why? You would like to  show / hide buttons when form is dirty / pristine, etc... 


Please, focus atleast on posiblities to "auto mark" components  by reactive forms directives like formControl, formControlName etc. It is very usable (it eliminates big part of component boiler plate) and it is very cheap (call on markForCheck()). When you have time, think about reactive solution to update value of form parts...

because setValue/patchValue is not a reactive way (calling methods != reactive) .

Thank you for your work, cannot wait for new NG 8.0! 

### Describe the solution you'd like
1) auto markforcheck in reactive forms directive
2) provide a way to reactively set form control value [formControl]="name" [formControlValue]="person.name"

to eliminate
@Input
set person(value: Person) {
 this.form.get('name').setValue(value.name);
}

3) statusChanges should notify about all status changes - like Router does.  We can still filter events by type.

4) Provide reactive way to disable /enable form.


### Describe alternatives you've considered
Template driven forms. Custom directives to disable / enable formControl, etc.

Issues.Title: feat(forms): formControlName also accepts a number
Issues.Body:
## PR Checklist Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements: - [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit - [ ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features) - [x] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features) ## PR Type What kind of change does this PR introduce? - [ ] Bugfix - [x] Feature - [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables) - [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes) - [ ] Build related changes - [ ] CI related changes - [ ] Documentation content changes - [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes - [ ] Other... Please describe: ## What is the current behavior? Currently, when using a `FormArray`, most templates look like: ```html
``` Here `formControlName` receives a number whereas its input type is a string. This is fine for VE and `fullTemplateTypeCheck`, but not for Ivy which does a more thorough type checking on inputs with `fullTemplateTypeCheck` enabled and throws `Type 'number' is not assignable to type 'string'`. It is fixable by using `formControlName="{{i}}"` but you have to know the difference between `a="{{b}}"` and `[a]="b"` and change it all over the application codebase. ## What is the new behavior? This commit relaxes the type of the `formControlName` input to accept both a `string` and a `number`. ## Does this PR introduce a breaking change? - [ ] Yes - [x] No ## Other information This has been discussed with @kara on Slack. Note that this PR contains two commits: - the first one relaxes the input type to `string | number` by changing it on the base `NgControl` class - the second one reverts #29473 , where @piotrtomiak ran into a similar issue and changed the example in the docs to help users avoid it. It is now no longer necessary, and the example uses `[formControlName]="i"` again, as all the other examples in the codebase. Also note that no tests were added as the issue is already caught by our tests when `fullTemplateTypeCheck` is on, but it is currently disabled until Ivy type-checking is on par with VE (see FW-1004). For example, adding `type_check=True` in https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/packages/examples/forms/BUILD.bazel#L12-L14 surfaces the issue.

Issues.Title: Pass extra terser options through the angular.json
Issues.Body:
# 🚀 Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ✍️edit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description

Right now I can't just add these extra terser options to a custom webpack config and expect it to work because the "bundleOptimizer: true" option would just overwrite the whole thing. (Given the nature of the config I'm not expecting that this would be possible anytime, hence this proposal:) If I'd to disable that, I'd need to re-implement the whole thing just to change one option. And when I do it naively with a simple setup it straight up fails. (Probably because ng8 now builds both legacy and modern bundles and would require different setups, as I've seen that in this repo where the default config is assembled. But I have no way differentiating that in a custom config file.)

### Describe the solution you'd like

Add a terserOptions config option -- which accepts an object -- into the project's angular.json config (under architect.build.configurations.production). And merge it into the default terserOptions object if exists. (This one here: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/74f2ee68d6d166903d5ef571d8a793bd4994e142/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/angular-cli-files/models/webpack-configs/common.ts#L284)

### Use-case

I'd like to have the terser option "keep_classnames" turned on (set to a set of classes which are to be persisted) because of a serialization/deserialization mechanic that resolves the class that belongs to a JSON (stored in a database) by the name of the class. If the name of the class is minified,  these persistent, serialized objects would not be cross-compatible between dev and prod builds. Also there's no guarantee that between different prod versions these minified class names wouldn't change over time.

Issues.Title: fix(@ngtools/webpack): downlevel constructor parameter type information
Issues.Body:
The Angular JIT compiler uses the output of TypeScript's `emitDecoratorMetadata` to support dependency injection at runtime.  This option stores type and DI token information so that the runtime JIT compiler can inject the proper provider.  This option is not needed for AOT compilation and the metadata is indirectly stripped from the output due to all Angular decorators being removed during the compilation process.

Unfortunately, the `emitDecoratorMetadata` option does not support forward references (or more generally circular dependencies) within ES2015+ output due to the TypeScript compiler transforming the metadata into a direct reference of the yet to be defined class.  This results in a runtime TDZ error.  This is a known limitation of the `emitDecoratorMetadata` option ([reference](https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/issues/27519)).  This situation is not unique to Angular and can occur in any TypeScript code.  As it is marked as a design limitation, it is considered that it cannot be fixed within the current architecture of TypeScript.

As a result, the change in this PR removes the need for the use of the option by storing the DI information in a static property function via the use of the tsickle `ctorParameters` transformation.  By leveraging the existing functionality, no changes to the framework code is necessary.  Also, minimal new code is required within the CLI, as the relevant tsickle code can be extracted and used with several local modifications.

For forward references to function in ES2015+, the `emitDecoratorMetadata` option must be disabled based on the current implementation.  To support both the option and forward references, the metadata generated by TypeScript would need to be altered to remove the type information that would trigger a TDZ error.  However, by doing so the metadata information is no longer useful to Angular and technically incorrect as it will not contain the information from the source code as described by the option.

Closes: #14424

Issues.Title: feat(cdk-experimental/testing): Bring in component harness
Issues.Body:
This is the initial PR bringing in the the `ComponentHarness` from google3. Huge thanks to @qiyigg and @vikerman for getting this started, and to all who contributed to the code in google3.

## Main files
* `cdk-experimental/testing/component-harness.ts` contains classes and interfaces that define the test-environment-independent component harness
  * `ComponentHarness` the base class for all harnesses
  * `TestElement` an interface used by the `ComponentHarness` to interface with the DOM
  * `Locator` an interface used by the `ComponentHarness` to find `TestElement`s

* `cdk-experimental/testing/testbed.ts` contains implementation specific to Angular's `TestBed`
  * `TestBed` compatible implementations of `TestElement` and `Locator`
  * `load` method used to create instances of `ComponentHarness` that are compatible with `TestBed`
  * Depends on `@angular/core/testing`

* `cdk-experimental/testing/protractor.ts` contains implementation specific to Protractor.
  * Protractor compatible implementations of `TestElement` and `Locator`
  * `load` method used to create instances of `ComponentHarness` that are compatible with `TestBed`
  * Depends on `protractor` and `selenium-webdriver`

* `cdk-experimental/testing/test-app/*` a simple app that exists to serve as a testing ground to run e2e and unit tests that use `ComponentHarness`

## Questions
* Is it ok that `testbed.ts` and `protractor.ts` live inside `cdk-experimental` but have dependencies on `@angular/core/testing` and `protractor` respectively? We obviously don't want `cdk` to have a dependency on `protractor` in the future.
  * Option 1: Leave everything in `cdk-experimental` and just don't add `protractor` to `package.json`
  * Option 2: Move all of the cdk testing stuff to its own package
  * Option 3: Move just the environment files (`testbed.ts`, `protractor.ts`) to some other package

* How should the tests of the harness code itself be structured? It's weird to have the test-app nested under `cdk-experimental/testing` but its nice to have the tests themselves (`testbed.spec.ts`, `protractor.e2e.spec.ts`) co-located with the code.

## Future work
* Have the harness know it's component's root selector
* Add convenience method for checking CSS classes
* Fix protractor implementation of `focs`/`blur`
* Add ability for testbed implementation to detect `fakeAsync` tests
* Refactor names and structure of some of the objects (e.g. `load`)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR " feat(cdk-experimental/testing): Bring in component harness" (#16089)

Issues.Title: Make cdk-table extensible
Issues.Body:
The docs say:
> "Think of the CDK as a blank state of well-tested functionality upon which you can develop your own bespoke components."

I'd like to think of it like that, but that is not reflected by reality. In reality, much of the codebase is unnecessarily marked private, and writing bespoke components on top of it is virtually impossible, unless they match the exact use-cases permitted by the authors to enable the Material component framework.

For example, I have been trying to write a custom table component on top of CdkTable. At every turn, I have ran into limitations imposed by the base component's insistence on making vital data private. Simple things like accessing the rendered rows or the definitions are impossible.

If the CDK is genuinely intended to be a development kit, it should default to making data and functionality available to subclasses, not locking down its API as it would be in an end-product component suite. This might make the CDK authors' lives easier, but it is completely contrary to the philosophy of a useful development kit, which should be open to extensibility and unforeseen use-cases, not reflexively hostile to them.

The PR makes a start by marking the private fields and methods of CdkTable protected, so they can be accessed and override in a subclass.

Issues.Title: MatExpansionPanel animates header height when first rendered
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
Given an expansion panel with a header `<mat-expansion-panel-header collapsedHeight="10rem" expandedHeight="10rem">` it should be initially rendered at the specified height.

#### What is the current behavior?
The header is rendered at it's standard height, then animates to the specified height

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
[StackBlitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-48ryox?embed=1&file=app/expansion-overview-example.html)

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
Angular 7x, Material 7x
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "MatExpansionPanel animates header height when first rendered" (#16067)
